§ 4.4 Continued

Goal: Solve

(*)
x≡a1(mod m1)x \equiv a_1 (mod \space m_1)x≡a​1​​(mod m​1​​)
x≡a2(mod m2)x \equiv a_2 (mod \space m_2)x≡a​2​​(mod m​2​​)
 \space 
⋮\vdots⋮
 \space 
x≡an(mod mn)x \equiv a_n (mod \space m_n)x≡a​n​​(mod m​n​​)

Method 1: Chinese Remainder Theorem

Theorem 4.4.2

Let m1,m2,⋯,mnm_1,m_2, \cdots , m_nm​1​​,m​2​​,⋯,m​n​​ satisfy
i) mi>1   where ∀i∈[1,n]i) \space m_i > 1 \space \space \space where \space \forall i \in [1,n]i) m​i​​>1   where ∀i∈[1,n]
ii) gcd(mi,mj)>1   where ∀i≠j[1,n]ii) \space gcd(m_i ,m_j) > 1 \space \space \space where \space \forall i \neq j [1,n]ii) gcd(m​i​​,m​j​​)>1   where ∀i≠j[1,n]
Then the system (*) has a unique solution module
m=m1m2⋯mnm = m_1 m_2 \cdots m_nm=m​1​​m​2​​⋯m​n​​

i.e. any two solutions x = A and x = B will satisfy
A≡B(mod m)A \equiv B (mod \space m)A≡B(mod m)

 \space 

Proof

Define


Mk=mmk=m1⋅m2⋯mk−1⋅mk+1⋯mnM_k = \frac{m}{m_k} = m_1 \cdot m_2 \cdots m_{k-1} \cdot m_{k+1} \cdots m_nM​k​​=​m​k​​​​m​​=m​1​​⋅m​2​​⋯m​k−1​​⋅m​k+1​​⋯m​n​​
Since Mk=m1⋅m2⋯mk−1⋅mk+1⋯mnM_k = m_1 \cdot m_2 \cdots m_{k-1} \cdot m_{k+1} \cdots m_nM​k​​=m​1​​⋅m​2​​⋯m​k−1​​⋅m​k+1​​⋯m​n​​
gcd(Mk,mk)=1gcd(M_k, m_k) = 1gcd(M​k​​,m​k​​)=1

By Theorem 4.4.1 ∃M¯∈Z\exists \bar M \in \mathbb{Z}∃​M​¯​​∈Z such that

MnM¯n≡1(mod mn)M_n \bar M_n \equiv 1 (mod \space m_n)M​n​​​M​¯​​​n​​≡1(mod m​n​​)

x=a1M1M¯1+a2M2M¯2+⋯+anMnM¯nx = a_1M_1 \bar M_1 + a_2M_2 \bar M_2 + \cdots + a_nM_n \bar M_nx=a​1​​M​1​​​M​¯​​​1​​+a​2​​M​2​​​M​¯​​​2​​+⋯+a​n​​M​n​​​M​¯​​​n​​ is a solution to (*)

Proof:


Notice for ∀J≠k∈[1,n]\forall J \neq k \in [1,n]∀J≠k∈[1,n]
Mj≡0 (mod mk)M_j \equiv 0 \space (mod \space m_k)M​j​​≡0 (mod m​k​​)
Because Mj=mmj=m1⋅m2⋯mj−1⋅mj+1⋯mk⋯mnM_j = \frac{m}{m_j} = m_1 \cdot m_2 \cdots m_{j-1} \cdot m_{j+1} \cdots m_k \cdots m_nM​j​​=​m​j​​​​m​​=m​1​​⋅m​2​​⋯m​j−1​​⋅m​j+1​​⋯m​k​​⋯m​n​​

i.e. mk∣Mjm_k | M_jm​k​​∣M​j​​

Hence x=a1M1M¯1+⋯+anMnM¯nx = a_1M_1 \bar M_1 + \cdots + a_n M_n \bar M_nx=a​1​​M​1​​​M​¯​​​1​​+⋯+a​n​​M​n​​​M​¯​​​n​​
x=0+⋯+akMkM¯kx = 0+ \cdots + a_kM_k \bar M_kx=0+⋯+a​k​​M​k​​​M​¯​​​k​​
x≡anMkM¯k(mod mk)x \equiv a_nM_k \bar M_k (mod \space m_k)x≡a​n​​M​k​​​M​¯​​​k​​(mod m​k​​)
x≡ak(mod mk)  x \equiv a_k (mod \space m_k) \space \spacex≡a​k​​(mod m​k​​)   where  ∀k∈[1,n]\space \forall k \in [1,n] ∀k∈[1,n]
Hence x=a1M1M¯1+a2M2M¯2+⋯+anMnM¯nx = a_1M_1 \bar M_1 + a_2M_2 \bar M_2 + \cdots + a_nM_n \bar M_nx=a​1​​M​1​​​M​¯​​​1​​+a​2​​M​2​​​M​¯​​​2​​+⋯+a​n​​M​n​​​M​¯​​​n​​

 \space 
 \space 
 \space 

Example 1

Solve

x≡2(mod 3)x \equiv 2 (mod \space 3)x≡2(mod 3)
x≡3(mod 5)x \equiv 3 (mod \space 5)x≡3(mod 5)
x≡2(mod 7)x \equiv 2 (mod \space 7)x≡2(mod 7)

e.g.
m=3⋅5⋅7=105m = 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 = 105m=3⋅5⋅7=105
m1=5⋅7=35m_1 = 5 \cdot 7 = 35m​1​​=5⋅7=35
M¯1=−1\bar M_1 = -1​M​¯​​​1​​=−1
In general:
M1=mm1=1053=5⋅7M_1 = \frac{m}{m_1} = \frac{105}{3} = 5 \cdot 7M​1​​=​m​1​​​​m​​=​3​​105​​=5⋅7

Need M¯1∈ZNeed \space \bar M_1 \in \mathbb{Z}Need ​M​¯​​​1​​∈Z
M¯1⋅35≡(mod 3)\bar M_1 \cdot 35 \equiv ( mod \space 3)​M​¯​​​1​​⋅35≡(mod 3)
M¯1⋅M1≡(mod m1)\bar M_1 \cdot M_1 \equiv ( mod \space m_1)​M​¯​​​1​​⋅M​1​​≡(mod m​1​​)
M¯1=−1\bar M_1 = -1​M​¯​​​1​​=−1
 \space 

M¯2=3⋅7=21\bar M_2 = 3 \cdot 7 = 21​M​¯​​​2​​=3⋅7=21
Need M¯2Need \space \bar M_2Need ​M​¯​​​2​​
M¯2⋅21≡(mod 5)\bar M_2 \cdot 21 \equiv ( mod \space 5)​M​¯​​​2​​⋅21≡(mod 5)
M¯2=1\bar M_2 = 1​M​¯​​​2​​=1
 \space 

M¯3=3⋅5=15\bar M_3 = 3 \cdot 5 = 15​M​¯​​​3​​=3⋅5=15
Need M¯3Need \space \bar M_3Need ​M​¯​​​3​​
M¯3⋅15≡1(mod 7)\bar M_3 \cdot 15 \equiv 1 ( mod \space 7)​M​¯​​​3​​⋅15≡1(mod 7)
M¯3=1\bar M_3 = 1​M​¯​​​3​​=1
 \space 

Check
x=a1M1M¯1+a2M2M¯2+a3M3M¯3x = a_1M_1 \bar M_1 + a_2M_2 \bar M_2 + a_3M_3 \bar M_3x=a​1​​M​1​​​M​¯​​​1​​+a​2​​M​2​​​M​¯​​​2​​+a​3​​M​3​​​M​¯​​​3​​
   =(2)(35)(−1)+(3)(21)(1)+(2)(15)(1)\space \space \space = (2)(35)(-1) + (3)(21)(1)+(2)(15)(1)   =(2)(35)(−1)+(3)(21)(1)+(2)(15)(1)
   =23\space \space \space = 23   =23
x≡23(mod 105)x \equiv 23 (mod \space 105)x≡23(mod 105)
x−23=105kx - 23 = 105 kx−23=105k
x=105k+23x = 105k +23x=105k+23
